title: PM Update: Clearing out overnight with cooler temperatures
text:
Hoping for a win in the final game at Nationals Park this season. (Wolfkann/Flickr)

It’s safe to say the weather was less than ideal for this morning’s Marine Corps Marathon. Upward of one to two inches of rain fell across the area over the past 24 hours, the bulk of which came during a particularly heavy band of rain from 10 a.m. to noon. And did you notice the humidity? Dew points briefly jumped into the 70s! Thankfully, the rain and the summerlike humidity have departed before first pitch of the crucial World Series game happening in town tonight.

Listen to our daily D.C. forecasts: Apple Podcasts | Amazon Echo | More options

Through tonight: Continuing to dry out with mostly clear skies. Temperatures will be falling through the 60s during Game 5, with a cool breeze out of the northwest at about 10 mph. Winds will become calm overnight, and with mostly clear skies in place, temperatures will drop into the upper 40s outside the Beltway, lower 50s closer to Interstate 95 and the city.

View the current weather at The Washington Post.

Tomorrow (Monday): High pressure will build in from the west on Monday, leading to some rather warm and pleasant weather. Temperatures will make a run at 70 degrees (most locations settle for the upper 60s) before some cloud cover builds in by the late afternoon as winds become more easterly. Partly cloudy and seasonable tomorrow night with temperatures in the low 50s.

See Brian Jackson’s forecast through this week. And if you haven’t already, join us on Facebook and follow us on Twitter and Instagram. For related traffic news, check out Gridlock.

Little Pablo: You may not have been paying attention, but there is a tropical system way out in the Atlantic. Hurricane Pablo isn’t a big storm, but its very existence in its current location is enough for a record.

#Pablo is now a #hurricane. It became a hurricane at 18.3°W - the farthest east an Atlantic named storm has first become a hurricane on record - breaking the old record set by Vince in 2005 (18.9°W). pic.twitter.com/f3Nwh8vXtY — Philip Klotzbach (@philklotzbach) October 27, 2019

description: The rain is gone, as is the unseasonable humidity.
